docs.lead_paragraph: Sukhinder Singh Cassidy, Google's former president of Asia-Pacific and Latin America operations, is taking on a new challenge. She will become chief executive of Polyvore, an online shopping and fashion start-up company. Ms. Singh Cassidy left Google in April to join Accel, a venture capital firm, as a chief in residence, with plans to join or start a young company.

docs.snippet: The digital masses, however, don't have a great record at prognostication: last year they were chattering about Brad Pitt and Kate Winslet, but only Ms. Winslet won....
docs.lead_paragraph: Online data metrics are notoriously unreliable - do you count clicks or visits? Google searches or blog mentions? - but that doesn't stop people from using it. Nielsen Media reports that "Avatar" far outstrips the other best picture contenders in online "buzz," which is presumably counted in the traditional way, via abacus. Its main competition, "The Hurt Locker," comes in second and - apologies to Harvey Weinstein - "Inglourious Basterds" ranks dead last.

headline.main: The Na'vi Capture the Online Buzz

docs.snippet: A creative director of Google finds inspiration in a rare place: the ceiling....
docs.lead_paragraph: Blank space is a blank canvas for Ji Lee. "I'm interested in exploring areas like the back of business cards and ceilings - why are they left empty?" says the renegade graphic designer, who is currently working as creative director of Google's branding and marketing unit, the Creative Lab. To fill the void above, Lee creates miniature upside-down interiors that he calls "parallel worlds," placing them on domestic ceilings (on commission) and corporate offices (on the sly). "Decorating ceilings was a common art form that somehow got lost through the reductionism of modernism," he says. The Lilliputian lairs are meticulously furnished with objects that tell a story about the "room" and its imaginary owner. One installation shows the apartment of a rocker, complete with a guitar, amp, microphone and Jimi Hendrix poster. Another, installed in a home with two small children, features a petit bourgeois living room with velvet sofas and tiny glass cabinets filled with strange furry objects made of cat hair. "The kids love it," Lee says. "That's the greatest compliment." Go to pleaseenjoy.com.

headline.main: Off the Wall

docs.abstract: A creative director of Google finds inspiration in a rare place: the ceiling.

But instead, the company found itself facing a firestorm of angry users and awash in criticism from privacy advocates and bloggers.

docs.snippet: Like all corporate symbols, Google's doodles are intended to tell us something about the company. So, what is it trying to say?...
docs.lead_paragraph: Imagine that you and a fellow Stanford computer science grad have just been given a $100,000 check to bankroll a new business. The Burning Man festival is coming up, and you both want to go. What do you do? If you're Google's Sergey Brin and Larry Page, you make a rough sketch of the wooden effigy that's burned at the festival, add it to your Web site as an as an "Out of Office" sign and set off for the Nevada desert.

docs.snippet: There is the television set. There is the Web. And there are television shows on the Web. But the Web on the television set? Some say television is a ''lean back'' medium, unsuited to the forward-curving spines of this Web-surfing epoch. But The N...
docs.lead_paragraph: There is the television set. There is the Web. And there are television shows on the Web. But the Web on the television set? Some say television is a ''lean back'' medium, unsuited to the forward-curving spines of this Web-surfing epoch. But The New York Times reported last week that Google and Intel have joined the effort to marry the two media, teaming up with Sony to develop Google TV. The idea: You'll be able to curl up on a living room couch, Google your blind date, watch an endless stream of cat videos from YouTube and then tweet your friends about it all as easily as you now switch from ESPN to HBO to the Travel Channel. Perhaps one more step on the way to Google ubiquity. Click.

docs.snippet: China's government feels much more fragile than it lets on. And that's one reason for its crackdown on Google....
docs.lead_paragraph: Americans tend to think of China as this vast, unstoppable, titanic force. Some would add menacing. But the confrontation unfolding today between China and Google is a reminder that the Politburo sees the situation very differently. They see a fragile China besieged on all sides, challenged at home, desperately needing to churn out economic growth to sustain its political model. In short, they see vulnerability where we tend to see invincibility -- and that's one reason they took so tough a line on Google.

headline.main: China and Google

docs.abstract: China's government feels much more fragile than it lets on. And that's one reason for its crackdown on Google.

docs.snippet: PARIS -- The European Union's highest court on Tuesday gave Google broad latitude to sell advertising spots to rivals of trademarked brands when users do searches for   names like Louis Vuitton. But it also  said that the search engine might have ...
docs.lead_paragraph: PARIS -- The European Union's highest court on Tuesday gave Google broad latitude to sell advertising spots to rivals of trademarked brands when users do searches for names like Louis Vuitton. But it also said that the search engine might have to do more to protect brand owners from infringements. In a case brought by the luxury goods company LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton, the European Court of Justice said Google should not be required to block sales of brand names as advertising keywords. However, the judges said advertisers, or Google, could be liable for trademark violations in individual cases.

headline.main: Europe Lets Google Sell Brand Advertising

docs.abstract: European Court of Justice rules Google has broad latitude to sell advertising spots to rivals of trademarked brands when users do searches for names; says Google might have to do more to protect brand owners from infringements; suits were brought by LVMH Noet Hennessy Louis Vuitton and other brand owners (M)

docs.snippet: Google has stopped censoring results on its Chinese search engine, but many underlying pages are still blocked. Meanwhile, some Chinese say Google risks a government shutdown of its service, which would deprive them of its benefits on all topics....
docs.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG -- As Google began offering uncensored search results in China early Tuesday morning, it was unclear how much impact the company's move would have toward the company's stated goal: to "meaningfully increase access to information for people in China."

headline.main: What Happens as Google Uncensors Search in China?

docs.abstract: Google has stopped censoring results on its Chinese search engine, but many underlying pages are still blocked. Meanwhile, some Chinese say Google risks a government shutdown of its service, which would deprive them of its benefits on all topics.

docs.snippet: A look at news of interest in the San Francisco Bay Area....
docs.lead_paragraph: Marijuana Proposal Appeals to Need for Green | Proponents of the ballot measure to legalize marijuana in California won't dwell on the drug's safety or social acceptance. Instead, they will focus on money: They say that taxing its sales could raise $1.4 billion and ease the $20 billion state deficit. The measure, which qualified for the November ballot on Wednesday, would allow licensed retailers to sell up to one ounce at a time, a transaction that would be subject to tax. "We need the tax money," said Richard Lee, founder of Oaksterdam University, a trade school in Oakland for marijuana growers. Mr. Lee backed the ballot measure's successful petition drive. "Second, we need the tax savings on police and law enforcement, and have that law enforcement directed towards real crime." Some are not so sure. "We just don't think any good is going to come from this," said John Standish, president of the California Peace Officers Association. [The New York Times]

headline.main: Sampler: Pitching Marijuana for the Revenue, and the Last Day for Google Broadband Applications

docs.snippet: The percentage of visitors who came back to the top sites in the week ended March 20 mostly increased from the same period last year. Repeat visitors, as defined by Hitwise, are those that return to a Web site within 30 days, and advertisers value...
docs.lead_paragraph: The percentage of visitors who came back to the top sites in the week ended March 20 mostly increased from the same period last year. Repeat visitors, as defined by Hitwise, are those that return to a Web site within 30 days, and advertisers value them. The numbers can be deceptive. As a site like Facebook or YouTube, above, gains new users who return, the percentage of new users falls. Most of the popular sites saw a drop in the percentage of new visitors: Facebook saw a decrease of 57 percent, Windows Live Mail of 36 percent and Google of 2 percent. SHELLY FREIERMAN

headline.main: Popular Demand
